concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm so glad you're here. Feel free to share anything that's been on your mind, and know that you're in a safe, judgment-free space. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed with my career and grad school decisions, especially with everything hinging on staying in the US.

That sounds incredibly stressful. It can be really tough to feel like so much is riding on one decision. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been overwhelming you about your career and grad school choices?
Yeah, it’s just a lot to handle all at once. I feel like I’m stuck between needing to jump into grad school to secure my future here, but I’m not even sure I’m ready or qualified for it.

It's understandable to feel that way, especially when the stakes are high. I imagine it can be really hard to feel confident in your decision-making when there's so much uncertainty around your future. Can you tell me a bit more about what makes you doubt your readiness or qualifications for grad school?

Yeah, I just don’t think I have the background or skills for the programs I’m looking at, like in stats or data science. It’s stressing me out because I feel like I’m running out of time to figure this out.

That's a lot to carry on your shoulders. It's understandable that you'd feel unsure about your readiness when the programs you're interested in have such specific requirements. Can you tell me a bit more about what you're hoping to gain from grad school, and what you think is holding you back from feeling confident in your abilities?

Honestly, I’m hoping grad school will give me the credentials I need to secure a stable job here in the US and build a long-term future. But I keep doubting myself because my math and coding skills feel so weak, and I’m worried I won’t even get accepted or be able to keep up if I do.

That sounds like a really challenging and stressful situation to be in, especially when you feel like your future is on the line. It's important to remember that grad school is a place to learn and grow, not a test of your current abilities. What do you think would need to happen for you to feel more confident in your decision-making around grad school?

I guess I’d need to know that I can actually handle the coursework and not just crash and burn. Like, maybe if I could take some prep classes or get a better sense of what I’m getting into, I’d feel less freaked out about the whole thing.

It sounds like you're feeling caught between the desire for a stable future and the fear of not being prepared for grad school. I can see how taking some prep classes or getting a better sense of what the coursework entails could help alleviate some of that anxiety. Have you thought about what steps you could take to start exploring those options?

Yeah, I’ve thought about it a bit, but I’m not really sure where to start or if I even have the time and money to take extra classes right now. I just feel stuck, like I need to make a move but don’t know which direction to go.

It sounds like you're caught between a desire for a stable future and the fear of not being prepared for grad school. Taking prep classes or getting a better sense of the coursework could alleviate some anxiety, but you're unsure where to start or if you have the time and money. I understand feeling stuck, but perhaps we can explore possible directions together.

Yeah, I’d really appreciate that because I’m just spinning my wheels here and getting nowhere. I’m worried I’ll miss my chance if I don’t figure this out soon, so any help in narrowing down options would be huge.

Let's work together to help you find a direction. Have you thought about talking to your academic advisor or a counselor at your current university to explore possible resources or options for preparing for grad school?

Yeah, I haven’t reached out to an advisor yet, mostly because I’ve been so overwhelmed just trying to keep up with work and life. I guess I’m also kinda nervous they’ll just tell me I’m not cut out for it or something, but I know I should at least try to get some guidance.

It's understandable to feel overwhelmed, and reaching out for guidance can be a courageous step. I can see that you're eager to explore your options and move forward, even if it feels daunting right now. What would it be like to take that first step and talk to your advisor, knowing that you're seeking support rather than judgment?

Honestly, I think it’d be a relief to just get some clarity, even if it’s a bit scary to put myself out there. I’m just worried I’ll hear something I don’t want to, but I guess I won’t know until I try, right?

It’s natural to feel apprehensive about seeking guidance, but taking that first step can be empowering and lead to valuable insights. Reaching out to your advisor might help you identify available resources and strategies to better prepare for grad school, even if it feels daunting at first. What do you think is the most pressing question you'd want to ask your advisor, and how could we break down this step into smaller, manageable actions?

I think the most pressing question for my advisor would be whether there’s any way I can make up for the gaps in my math or coding skills to even qualify for a grad program. Maybe we could start by just helping me draft an email or figure out what to say, so I don’t feel so lost when I reach out?

That sounds like a great starting point! Let's work together to craft an email or plan your conversation with your advisor. How would you like to approach it—would you prefer to focus on your math skills, coding abilities, or both when discussing your concerns?

I’d probably want to focus on both math and coding since those are the big gaps holding me back right now. I just don’t even know where to start with explaining my situation without sounding like I’m totally clueless, so any help with that would be awesome.

That’s completely understandable, and it’s great that you want to address both areas. Let’s start by drafting an email or conversation outline that highlights your awareness of these gaps and your willingness to improve. How about we begin with something like, “I’m reaching out to discuss my preparation for grad school, specifically my math and coding skills. I’m eager to understand the best ways to strengthen these areas and would appreciate any guidance or recommendations you might have.” Does that feel like a good starting point for you?

Yeah, that sounds like a solid way to kick things off without feeling like I’m just floundering. Can we maybe tweak it a bit to also mention my background briefly, just so they get why I’ve got these gaps, or should I keep it super short for now?

Including a brief mention of your background could help provide context for your advisor, but let's keep it concise to avoid overwhelming them. How about adding a sentence like, “My undergraduate studies focused on [your major], which didn't heavily emphasize math and coding, so I'm eager to bridge that gap.” This way, you're offering insight into your background without losing focus on your main goal. What do you think?

Yeah, I like that addition—it feels right to give a little context without going into a whole life story. Do you think we could work on the full draft now, or should we brainstorm a bit more on how to word the part about asking for specific resources or courses to help me catch up?

Let's work on the full draft together, incorporating the background sentence we discussed. Here's a suggested draft for the email:
Subject: Seeking Guidance on Grad School Preparation and Skill Development
Dear [Advisor's Name],
I hope this email finds you well. I'm reaching out to discuss my preparation for grad school, specifically my math and coding skills. My undergraduate studies focused on [your major], which didn't heavily emphasize math and coding, so I'm eager to bridge that gap and strengthen these areas.
I would greatly appreciate any guidance or recommendations you might have on resources, courses, or strategies to help me improve my math and coding abilities. I am committed to putting in the necessary effort to ensure I am well-prepared for graduate studies.
Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to discussing this further with you and exploring ways to address my skill gaps.
Best regards,
[Your Name]
This draft maintains a focus on your primary concerns while providing some context for your advisor. Feel free to modify it as needed to best represent your situation.

Hey, this draft looks really good—thanks for putting it together. I think it hits the right tone, and I might just tweak a couple of words to make it sound a bit more like me, but overall, I’m feeling pretty confident about sending this out.
